answer_latex:
and from this we see that the vector
$\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}$ is an eigenvector.
hints_html:
Recall that to solve for eigenvectors, we must solve \(\displaystyle (A-\lambda I)\mathbf{x} = \mathbf{0}\) for each eigenvalue.

Look at the result from the previous hint and attempt to find the eigenvectors by inspection. Alternatively, take each eigenvalue and row reduce the matrix \(\displaystyle A-\lambda I\) and then find the eigenvectors.

hints_raw:
Recall that to solve for eigenvectors, we must solve <math>\displaystyle(A-\lambda I)\mathbf{x} = \mathbf{0} </math> for each eigenvalue.
Look at the result from the previous hint and attempt to find the eigenvectors by inspection. Alternatively, take each eigenvalue and row reduce the matrix <math> \displaystyle A-\lambda I </math> and then find the eigenvectors.
question: 4 (b)
sols_html:
Refer to the previous part for the eigenvalue computations. For the eigenvalue \(\displaystyle \lambda = 1\)

\[\begin{aligned} A-I=\begin{bmatrix} 2 & 2\\ 2 & 2 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

and from this we see that the vector \(\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ -1 \end{bmatrix}\) is an eigenvector. For the \(\displaystyle \lambda = 5\) eigenvalue,

\[\begin{aligned} A-5I=\begin{bmatrix} -2 & 2\\ 2 & -2 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

and from this we see that the vector \(\begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}\) is an eigenvector.
statement_html:
Consider the matrix

\[\begin{aligned} A=\begin{bmatrix} 3 & 2\\ 2 & 3 \end{bmatrix}.\end{aligned}\]

For each eigenvalue of A, find an eigenvector.
